title: Options for taxpayers who need help paying a tax bill
section: If you can't pay in full
text: If you can’t pay your full IRS bill by the due date, you still have options. The IRS encourages you to file your return on time, pay as much as you reasonably can, and then set up a payment arrangement for the rest. Depending on your balance and situation, you may qualify for a short-term plan, a long-term installment agreement, an offer in compromise, or in rare hardship cases, a temporary delay of collection. Ignoring the bill usually leads to more penalties, interest, and possible collection actions.

title: Apply online for a payment plan
text: Many individual taxpayers can apply online for a payment plan with the IRS. The online system lets you request either a short-term payment plan or a longer-term monthly installment agreement, depending on how much you owe. If your request is approved, you’ll pay your balance over time instead of all at once. Setup fees and interest can still apply, but a plan can prevent more serious collection actions as long as you make payments on schedule.

title: Options for taxpayers who need help paying a tax bill
section: Short-term payment plan (180 days or less)
text: A short-term payment plan is for people who can pay their full balance within 180 days but not by the original due date. To qualify, your total amount owed typically must be under a set threshold that includes tax, penalties, and interest. There is usually no setup fee for this option, though penalties and interest continue to accrue until the balance is paid in full. This option is useful if you just need a few months to catch up.

title: Apply online for a payment plan
text: A long-term payment plan, also called an installment agreement, is designed for taxpayers who need more than 180 days to pay. You generally must owe less than a certain amount, and you agree to make fixed monthly payments until the balance is paid. There is usually a setup fee, which can be lower if you use direct debit or qualify for low-income relief. While interest and penalties continue, an approved agreement can reduce collection pressure and, in some cases, lower the failure-to-pay penalty rate.

title: Offer in compromise
section: What is an offer in compromise
text: An offer in compromise is an agreement with the IRS that may allow you to settle your tax debt for less than the full amount you owe. It is generally considered only when you cannot pay in full or doing so would create significant financial hardship. When reviewing an offer, the IRS looks at your ability to pay, income, necessary living expenses, and equity in assets. Most people should explore simpler options like payment plans before applying, because the offer process is detailed and not everyone qualifies.

title: Offer in compromise
text: To be eligible to apply for an offer in compromise, you generally must have filed all required tax returns, made required estimated payments, and not be in an open bankruptcy. The IRS also expects businesses to be current on required deposits. Taxpayers can use the Offer in Compromise Pre-Qualifier Tool to get a preliminary sense of whether they might qualify and what a reasonable offer amount could be. The final decision, however, depends on a full review of the completed application and supporting financial information.

title: Currently Not Collectible (CNC)
section: When the IRS may temporarily delay collection
text: If you agree you owe the tax but truly cannot pay anything toward your balance without failing to meet basic living expenses, the IRS may place your account in Currently Not Collectible status. In that status, the IRS generally does not levy your wages or bank account, but interest and penalties continue to accrue and future refunds may be taken. The IRS may ask for detailed financial information to decide whether you qualify and will periodically review your situation to see if your ability to pay has changed.

title: Penalty relief
text: Tax penalties can sometimes be reduced or removed if you qualify for relief. Common types of relief include first-time penalty abatement for people with a good filing history, reasonable cause relief when circumstances beyond your control prevented timely filing or payment, and statutory exceptions in limited situations. To request relief, you usually follow the instructions on your IRS notice, and in some cases you may need to submit a written request or Form 843 explaining your situation and providing supporting documentation.

title: Administrative penalty relief
text: First-time penalty abatement is an administrative waiver the IRS can grant to taxpayers who have a clean recent compliance history. To qualify, you generally must have filed all required returns, arranged to pay any tax due, and have no significant penalties for the prior three years. If you qualify, the IRS may remove certain failure-to-file or failure-to-pay penalties for a single tax period. If you do not meet the criteria, the IRS may still consider other forms of penalty relief, such as reasonable cause.

title: Understanding a federal tax lien
section: What a federal tax lien is
text: A federal tax lien is the government’s legal claim against your property when you neglect or refuse to pay a tax debt after the IRS has assessed it and sent you a bill. The lien can attach to your real estate, personal property, and financial assets. The IRS may file a public Notice of Federal Tax Lien to alert creditors that the government has rights to your property, which can affect your ability to get credit or sell assets. Filing and paying your taxes on time is the best way to avoid a lien.

title: What is a levy?
section: IRS levy and seizure of property
text: An IRS levy is a legal action that actually takes your property or money to satisfy a tax debt. Unlike a lien, which is just a claim, a levy can garnish wages, remove funds from your bank account, or seize and sell property such as vehicles or real estate. The IRS normally sends several notices, including a Final Notice of Intent to Levy and information about your right to a hearing, before issuing a levy. Responding early to these notices and arranging payment is usually the best way to avoid a levy.

title: What's the difference between a levy and a lien?
section: Comparing a lien and a levy
text: A federal tax lien and a levy are related but different collection tools. A lien is a legal claim the government has on your property when you don’t pay your tax debt; it protects the government’s interest and can be made public through a Notice of Federal Tax Lien. A levy goes further and actually takes property or money, such as wages or bank funds, to pay the debt. Understanding this difference helps taxpayers see why early action to resolve a balance is important, before the IRS escalates to a levy.

title: Understanding your CP504 notice
section: Final notice before levy on certain property
text: The CP504 notice is a serious letter from the IRS that serves as a Notice of Intent to Levy on certain property, such as your state tax refund. It tells you that you still have an unpaid balance and that the IRS plans to start enforced collection if you do not act. The notice explains that the IRS can seize eligible payments and may move toward other types of levy if the balance remains unresolved. To avoid this, taxpayers are urged to pay in full, set up a payment plan, or contact the IRS right away to discuss options.
